metadata.author: Claude (Opus 4.5)
metadata.purpose: ATLAS Morning Protocol form guides for voice-guided execution
metadata.personality: Lethal Gentleman - direct, efficient, no-nonsense coaching

usage_notes.voice_response: Cues are designed to be spoken via TTS. Keep concise and actionable.
usage_notes.pain_rule: ALL exercises: if pain greater than 3 out of 10, stop and modify or skip.

plantar_fascia_ball_roll.name: Plantar Fascia Ball Roll
plantar_fascia_ball_roll.setup: Sit in a chair with feet flat on the floor. Place a golf ball or lacrosse ball under the arch of one foot.
execution: Apply moderate pressure through your foot onto the ball.
Slowly roll the ball from just below the ball of your foot to just before your heel.
Focus on tender spots. Hold for 10-20 seconds on tight areas.
Continue rolling for 2-3 minutes per foot.
cues: Roll slowly. This is not a race.
Focus on the arch. Avoid the heel bone.

common_mistakes.mistake: Applying too much pressure or rolling aggressively.
common_mistakes.fix: Gentle and slow. Too much pressure increases inflammation. You want to break up adhesions, not create new ones.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rolling directly on the heel bone.
common_mistakes.fix: Stay on soft tissue. Stop just before the heel.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rushing through the exercise.
common_mistakes.fix: Slow, methodical rolling is more effective. Spend time on tight spots.

modifications.easier: Use a tennis ball for softer pressure.
modifications.harder: Stand and apply bodyweight through the ball. Or use a frozen golf ball for combined ice therapy.

toe_yoga.name: Toe Yoga
toe_yoga.setup: Sit or stand with feet flat on the floor. Weight distributed evenly.
execution: Lift only your big toe while keeping the other four toes pressed into the floor.
Lower the big toe, then lift only the four smaller toes while keeping the big toe down.
Alternate between these two movements.
Perform 15 repetitions of each movement per foot.
cues: Big toe up, others down. Then switch.
Keep the ball of foot grounded.
Control is the goal. Not speed.
If stuck, tap the top of your big toe to activate it.

common_mistakes.mistake: Lifting all toes together instead of isolating.
common_mistakes.fix: Start by physically pressing down the toes that should stay down. Build the mind-muscle connection.

common_mistakes.mistake: Allowing the ball of the foot to lift.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep the forefoot anchored. Only the toes move.

common_mistakes.mistake: Getting frustrated when it doesn't work immediately.
common_mistakes.fix: This is a neuromuscular exercise. Proprioception improves with practice.

modifications.easier: Rub the top of each toe before the movement to stimulate the muscles.
modifications.harder: Perform while standing with full bodyweight through the foot.

short_foot_exercise.name: Short Foot Exercise
short_foot_exercise.setup: Sit with feet flat on the floor, shoulder-width apart. Establish a tripod position: weight on big toe ball, little toe ball, and heel.
execution: Lift all toes off the ground while keeping the tripod points grounded.
While toes are raised, feel your arch naturally lift.
Slowly lower your toes back down while actively pulling the ball of your foot toward your heel.
Maintain the raised arch position with toes flat. Do not curl toes.
cues: Dome the arch. Do not curl the toes.

common_mistakes.mistake: Curling or gripping with the toes.
common_mistakes.fix: Toes stay flat and long. The movement comes from the intrinsic foot muscles pulling the ball of foot toward the heel.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using calf muscles to create the arch.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep calves relaxed. The work is all in the foot.

common_mistakes.mistake: Losing the arch when lowering toes.
common_mistakes.fix: Maintain active contraction as you lower. The arch should stay elevated.

modifications.easier: Keep toes slightly lifted throughout. Focus on the pulling sensation.
modifications.harder: Progress to single-leg standing while maintaining the short foot position.

calf_stretch_wall.name: Calf Stretch (Wall)
calf_stretch_wall.setup: Stand facing a wall, arm's length away. Step one foot back into a lunge position. Hands on wall at shoulder height.
execution: For gastrocnemius: Keep back leg straight, heel on floor. Lean forward until you feel stretch in upper calf.
For soleus: Bend the back knee slightly while keeping heel down. Feel stretch in lower calf.
Hold each position for 30 seconds.
Repeat 3 times per leg, per variation.

common_mistakes.mistake: Back heel lifting off the floor.
common_mistakes.fix: Reduce forward lean. Only go as far as you can with heel down.

common_mistakes.mistake: Bending the back knee during gastrocnemius stretch.
common_mistakes.fix: Lock out that back knee completely for the straight-leg variation.

common_mistakes.mistake: Bouncing or forcing the stretch.
common_mistakes.fix: Static hold. Breathe into the stretch. Let it release naturally.

modifications.easier: Reduce forward lean. Smaller range is fine to start.
modifications.harder: Elevate front foot on a step for deeper stretch. Or add a calf raise between stretches.

ankle_cars.name: Ankle CARs (Controlled Articular Rotations)
ankle_cars.setup: Sit or stand. Lift one foot off the ground. Keep the leg still from the knee up.
execution: Slowly trace the largest possible circle with your toes.
Move through full plantarflexion, inversion, dorsiflexion, and eversion.
Use muscular control, not momentum. Take 5-10 seconds per full rotation.
Complete 3-5 circles in each direction per ankle.
cues: Isolate the ankle. Knee stays still.
Explore the edges of your range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Moving too fast or using momentum.
common_mistakes.fix: CARs are about control at end ranges. Slower is harder and more effective.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting the knee or hip move to cheat range of motion.
common_mistakes.fix: Isolate the ankle completely. The movement is ONLY at the ankle joint.

common_mistakes.mistake: Making small, lazy circles.
common_mistakes.fix: Push into the fullest range at every point. Expand your circle over time.

modifications.easier: Seated with foot hanging freely removes balance demands.
modifications.harder: Add 50-100% tension. Act as if someone is resisting the movement with their hands.

banded_ankle_mobilization.name: Banded Ankle Mobilization (Posterior Talar Glide)
banded_ankle_mobilization.setup: Anchor a strong resistance band low to the ground. Loop it around the front of your ankle, just below the ankle bones. Face away from the anchor with band pulling backward.
execution: Place foot on ground in half-kneeling or split stance position.
The band should be pulling the talus posteriorly (back toward the anchor).
Keeping heel down, drive your knee forward over your toes.
Hold end range for 2-3 seconds, then return. Perform 10-15 repetitions.
cues: Band pulls the ankle bone back.
Feel the front of ankle open up.

common_mistakes.mistake: Band placed too high on the shin instead of at the ankle joint.
common_mistakes.fix: Band goes just below the ankle bones, directly on the talus.

common_mistakes.mistake: Heel lifting as knee drives forward.
common_mistakes.fix: Reduce depth. Only go as far as you can with heel down.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using a band that is too light.
common_mistakes.fix: You need substantial resistance to create the posterior glide. Use a thick band.

modifications.easier: Use a lighter band or reduce forward knee drive.
modifications.harder: Add weight by holding a kettlebell or dumbbell in goblet position.

eccentric_calf_raises.name: Eccentric Calf Raises
eccentric_calf_raises.setup: Stand on a step with heels hanging off the edge. Use a wall or rail for balance. Start in the raised position (on tiptoes).
execution: Use BOTH legs to raise up onto tiptoes (concentric phase is easy).
Shift weight to ONE leg and slowly lower that heel below the step level.
Take 3-5 seconds to lower (the eccentric phase is the work).
Return to start using both legs. Perform 3 sets of 15 reps per leg.
cues: Both legs up. One leg down.
Do not bounce at the bottom.

common_mistakes.mistake: Lowering too fast.
common_mistakes.fix: Count 3-5 seconds on every single rep. The slow eccentric is the entire point.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not going through full range of motion.
common_mistakes.fix: Lower until heel is below the step. Full stretch at bottom.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using the same leg to raise as to lower.
common_mistakes.fix: Bilateral concentric, unilateral eccentric. This is the Alfredson protocol.

modifications.easier: Perform bilateral eccentrics. Both legs lower together.
modifications.harder: Add load by holding dumbbells. Or perform bent-knee version for soleus emphasis.

ankle_alphabet.name: Ankle Alphabet
ankle_alphabet.setup: Sit or lie down with one leg extended. Foot should hang freely without touching the ground.
execution: Use your big toe as a pen to trace each letter of the alphabet in the air.
Make letters as large as possible to maximize range of motion.
Move only from the ankle. Keep shin and calf still.
Complete the entire alphabet per foot.

common_mistakes.mistake: Making tiny, lazy letters.
common_mistakes.fix: Exaggerate each letter. Larger movements mean more mobility work.

common_mistakes.mistake: Moving the entire leg instead of isolating the ankle.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep the shin completely still. All movement comes from the ankle down.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rushing through the alphabet.
common_mistakes.fix: This is rehabilitation, not a race. Quality over speed.

modifications.easier: Sit with leg supported. Less demand on hip flexors.
modifications.harder: Write in cursive. Or try lowercase and uppercase separately.

cat_cow.name: Cat-Cow
cat_cow.setup: Start on all fours. Hands directly under shoulders, knees directly under hips. Spine in neutral.
execution: COW: Inhale, drop belly toward floor, lift chest and tailbone, gaze forward.
CAT: Exhale, round spine toward ceiling, tuck chin to chest, tuck tailbone.
Flow smoothly between positions with your breath.
Perform 7-10 cycles.
cues: Inhale for cow. Exhale for cat.
Move like a wave through your spine.
Smooth and controlled. No jerky movements.

common_mistakes.mistake: Throwing head back during cow pose.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep neck long and in line with spine. Gentle gaze forward, not at ceiling.

common_mistakes.mistake: Only moving at one hinge point instead of the whole spine.
common_mistakes.fix: Feel each vertebra move sequentially. The wave should travel through entire spine.

common_mistakes.mistake: Holding breath.
common_mistakes.fix: Breath drives the movement. Inhale to extension, exhale to flexion.

modifications.easier: Reduce range of motion. Smaller movements are fine.
modifications.harder: Add a pause at end range of each position. Or perform seated version for different angle.

dead_bug.name: Dead Bug
dead_bug.setup: Lie on back. Knees bent at 90 degrees, thighs perpendicular to floor. Arms straight up toward ceiling, palms facing each other. Lower back pressed flat into floor.
execution: Brace core by drawing belly button toward spine.
Simultaneously extend right arm overhead and left leg forward, lowering both toward floor.
Keep lower back pressed into floor throughout.
Return to start and repeat with opposite arm and leg. That's one rep.

common_mistakes.mistake: Lower back arching off the floor.
common_mistakes.fix: Reduce range of motion. Don't extend as far until you can maintain flat back.

common_mistakes.mistake: Moving too fast.
common_mistakes.fix: Speed kills form. Slower movement means more core work.

common_mistakes.mistake: Holding breath.
common_mistakes.fix: Exhale as you extend limbs. Inhale as you return to start.

modifications.easier: Move only legs while arms stay up. Or move only arms while legs stay in tabletop.
modifications.harder: Add resistance band around feet. Or hold light weight in hands.

hip_flexor_stretch.name: Hip Flexor Stretch
equipment: mat or soft surface for knee
hip_flexor_stretch.setup: Half-kneeling position. Front foot flat on floor, knee at 90 degrees. Back knee on mat directly under hip. Torso tall.
execution: Tuck pelvis under (posterior pelvic tilt) by squeezing the glute of the back leg.
Gently shift weight forward while maintaining the pelvic tilt.
Feel stretch in front of back hip. Hold 30 seconds.
Repeat 2-3 times per side.
cues: Stay tall. Do not lean forward.

common_mistakes.mistake: Leaning torso forward to feel the stretch.
common_mistakes.fix: Stay vertical. The stretch comes from the posterior pelvic tilt and forward shift, not from leaning.

common_mistakes.mistake: Anterior pelvic tilt (arching lower back).
common_mistakes.fix: Tuck pelvis under aggressively. Squeeze that back glute. This is the key to the stretch.

common_mistakes.mistake: Knee sliding forward past toes.
common_mistakes.fix: Maintain a stable front shin angle. Shift hips forward, don't collapse into front knee.

modifications.easier: Keep hands on front thigh for balance support.
modifications.harder: Reach same-side arm overhead for increased stretch. Or elevate back foot on a couch for couch stretch variation.

glute_bridge.name: Glute Bridge
glute_bridge.setup: Lie on back, knees bent, feet flat on floor hip-width apart. Heels about 6-8 inches from glutes. Arms at sides, palms up.
execution: Flatten lower back into floor with a slight posterior pelvic tilt.
Drive through heels and squeeze glutes to lift hips toward ceiling.
Raise until body forms straight line from knees to shoulders.
Hold for 2-3 seconds at top, squeezing glutes hard. Lower with control.
cues: Straight line from knee to shoulder.
Don't arch your back at top.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arching lower back at the top instead of bridging with glutes.
common_mistakes.fix: Think about bringing ribs toward pelvis. Stop when body is straight, not when back is arched.

common_mistakes.mistake: Feeling it in hamstrings instead of glutes.
common_mistakes.fix: Bring feet closer to glutes. Focus on squeezing glutes before lifting.

common_mistakes.mistake: Pushing through toes.
common_mistakes.fix: Drive through heels. You should be able to lift your toes off the ground.

modifications.easier: Reduce range of motion. Don't lift as high.
modifications.harder: Single leg bridge. Or add band around knees and push out against resistance. Or add a pause at top.

clamshells.name: Clamshells (Glute Med Activation)
clamshells.setup: Lie on side with hips and knees bent at 90 degrees, knees stacked. Head rested on bottom arm. Top hand on hip to monitor for cheating.
execution: Keep feet together throughout the movement.
Rotate top knee toward ceiling as far as possible without letting hips roll backward.
Pause at top, squeezing glute med.
Lower with control. Perform 15-20 reps per side.
cues: Rotate from the hip. Not the back.
Top hand checks for hip roll.
Slow controlled lift. Pause at top.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rolling hips backward to cheat more range.
common_mistakes.fix: Top hand monitors hip. Zero rotation backward. If you can't lift high with stable hips, reduce range.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using momentum to swing knee up.
common_mistakes.fix: Slow and controlled. 2 seconds up, 2 seconds down.

common_mistakes.mistake: Not feeling it in the glute med (side of hip).
common_mistakes.fix: Roll forward slightly so top hand is in front of hip bone. This targets glutes, not hip flexors.

modifications.easier: Start with smaller range of motion. Build up over time.
modifications.harder: Add a mini band above knees for resistance.

bird_dog.name: Bird-Dog
bird_dog.setup: Start on all fours in tabletop position. Hands directly under shoulders, knees directly under hips. Spine in neutral.
execution: Brace core. Maintain neutral spine throughout.
Simultaneously extend right arm forward and left leg backward.
Keep arm and leg parallel to floor. Hold 2-5 seconds.
Return to start with control. Repeat with opposite arm and leg.
cues: Reach long. Fingers and toes away from each other.
No rotation. Hips and shoulders stay level.
If your water bottle would roll off your back, you're rotating.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arching lower back when extending leg.
common_mistakes.fix: Don't lift leg higher than hip level. Focus on reaching long, not high.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rotating hips or shoulders.
common_mistakes.fix: Imagine balancing a water bottle on your lower back. It shouldn't roll off.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rushing through repetitions.
common_mistakes.fix: Quality over quantity. Hold each position for 2-5 seconds with perfect form.

modifications.easier: Move only one limb at a time. Arm only, then leg only.
modifications.harder: Add a pause at end range. Or draw small circles with extended hand and foot.

doorframe_external_rotation.name: Doorframe External Rotation (Isometric)
doorframe_external_rotation.setup: Stand INSIDE doorframe facing out. Elbow bent 90 degrees, pinned to side, forearm points forward. Position BACK of wrist (knuckle side) against inside edge of doorframe. Palm faces your body.
execution: Try to rotate forearm outward like opening a door. Doorframe blocks the movement.
Push back of wrist into the frame. 30-40% effort. Gentle sustained push.
Elbow stays pinned to your side. Don't let it drift.
Hold for 45 seconds. Breathe normally throughout.
Rest 15-30 seconds. Repeat second hold.
cues: 30 percent effort. Like pressing into a balloon.
Elbow stays glued to your side.

common_mistakes.mistake: Pushing too hard.
common_mistakes.fix: This is rotator cuff activation, not a strength test. 30-40% effort maximum.

common_mistakes.mistake: Elbow drifting away from body.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep elbow pinned to your side throughout. Consider placing a towel between elbow and ribs.

common_mistakes.mistake: Shrugging shoulder up toward ear.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep shoulder blade down and back. Relaxed shoulder position.

modifications.easier: Use a folded towel between wrist and doorframe for comfort.
modifications.harder: Increase hold time to 30-60 seconds. Or progress to banded external rotation with movement.

towel_crush.name: Towel Crush (Isometric Internal Rotation)
towel_crush.setup: Stand or sit with good posture. Roll a towel and place it between your elbow and your side. Elbow bent to 90 degrees.
execution: Squeeze the towel between your arm and your body.
While squeezing, gently press palm toward your stomach.
Hold for 5-10 seconds at 30-40% effort.
Perform 6-10 repetitions. Repeat 2-3 times daily.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting elbow drift forward.
common_mistakes.fix: Elbow stays in line with torso. The towel helps keep position honest.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using too much force.
common_mistakes.fix: Isometric activation only. 30-40% max effort.

common_mistakes.mistake: Rounding shoulders forward.
common_mistakes.fix: Stand tall with shoulder blades lightly retracted. Good posture throughout.

modifications.easier: Perform seated for better body awareness.
modifications.harder: Progress to banded internal rotation with controlled movement.

band_pull_aparts.name: Band Pull-Aparts
band_pull_aparts.setup: Stand tall with feet shoulder-width apart. Hold a light resistance band at arms length in front of you. Hands shoulder-width apart, palms down.
execution: Keep arms straight throughout the movement.
Pull the band apart by squeezing shoulder blades together.
Continue until band touches chest and arms are out to sides.
Return with control. Perform 15-20 repetitions.
cues: Arms stay straight. No bending elbows.

common_mistakes.mistake: Shrugging shoulders up toward ears.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep shoulders depressed throughout. Think shoulder blades into back pockets.

common_mistakes.mistake: Bending elbows to cheat the movement.
common_mistakes.fix: Arms locked straight. All movement is from the shoulder blades.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using too heavy of a band.
common_mistakes.fix: This is a warm-up and activation exercise. Light band, high reps.

modifications.easier: Widen grip on band for less resistance.
modifications.harder: Narrow grip for more resistance. Or pause at end position for 2-3 seconds.

scapular_wall_slides.name: Scapular Wall Slides
scapular_wall_slides.setup: Stand with back against wall. Feet about 6 inches from wall. Back of head, upper back, and lower back touching wall. Arms at 90 degrees like a goal post, forearms on wall.
execution: Press forearms and backs of hands into the wall.
Slide arms up the wall while maintaining contact with forearms and hands.
Reach as high as possible while keeping all contact points.
Slide back down with control. Perform 10-15 repetitions.
cues: Forearms and hands stay on wall.
Push upper back away from wall as you slide up.
Don't arch lower back off wall.

common_mistakes.mistake: Losing contact between arms and wall.
common_mistakes.fix: Reduce range of motion. Only go as high as you can maintain contact.

common_mistakes.mistake: Arching lower back off the wall.
common_mistakes.fix: Keep core braced. Lower back maintains contact throughout.

common_mistakes.mistake: Shrugging shoulders toward ears.
common_mistakes.fix: Depress shoulder blades. Think shoulders away from ears.

modifications.easier: Move away from wall and use a foam roller against it for feedback. More room to move.
modifications.harder: Add a mini band around wrists and maintain outward tension throughout the slide.

thoracic_extensions.name: Thoracic Extensions (Foam Roller)
thoracic_extensions.setup: Lie on back with foam roller perpendicular under upper back, just below shoulder blades. Knees bent, feet flat on floor. Hands behind head to support neck.
execution: Keep chin tucked slightly like holding an egg under chin.
Let upper back extend over the foam roller. Reach back without forcing.
Hold for 2-3 breaths. Feel upper back opening.
Move roller slightly up or down to target different segments. Repeat at 3-4 positions.
cues: Extend upper back only. Not lower back.

common_mistakes.mistake: Letting head fall back and hyperextending neck.
common_mistakes.fix: Hands support head. Chin stays tucked. Only upper back extends.

common_mistakes.mistake: Placing roller on lower back.
common_mistakes.fix: Foam roller stays on thoracic spine (upper back). Never on lower back.

common_mistakes.mistake: Forcing range of motion.
common_mistakes.fix: Relax and breathe. Let gravity do the work. Don't push into pain.

modifications.easier: Use a softer roller or a rolled towel instead.
modifications.harder: Extend arms overhead during the stretch to increase the opening.

chin_tucks.name: Chin Tucks
chin_tucks.setup: Sit or stand tall with shoulders relaxed. Look straight ahead with ears over shoulders. Place a finger on your chin as a reference point.
execution: Without moving your finger, pull your chin straight back as if making a double chin.
Keep looking forward. Don't tilt head up or down.
Feel gentle stretch at base of skull and back of neck.
Hold 5-10 seconds. Perform 10-15 repetitions.
cues: Pull chin straight back. Not down.

common_mistakes.mistake: Tilting head down toward chest.
common_mistakes.fix: This is a retraction, not flexion. Pull chin straight back on a horizontal plane.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using too much force.
common_mistakes.fix: Gentle movement. You should feel a mild stretch, not strain.

common_mistakes.mistake: Holding breath or tensing shoulders.
common_mistakes.fix: Stay relaxed. Breathe normally. Only the neck moves.

modifications.easier: Lie on back with rolled towel under neck. Perform the same retraction motion.
modifications.harder: Add gentle overpressure with fingers on chin to increase range.
